conclusion: Analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to different positions by examining the physics of shadow formation and using the labeled image as reference.
A cork bulletin board on the left with various notes and pins (casting shadow C).
A small black object that appears to be a pen or stick (casting shadow A).
A ring or circular object (casting shadow B).
A white cylindrical/hexagonal object with a postcard leaning against it (casting shadow D).
A hand-shaped sculpture at the top of the image (not labeled with a shadow).
Shadows move in the opposite direction from the light source movement.
Shadows grow larger when the light source moves closer to the object.
Shadows become more elongated when the light source moves lower relative to the object.
Shadow sharpness decreases as the light source gets larger relative to the object.
If the light source moves to the back left, shadow A will move toward the front right.
Shadow A will elongate diagonally toward the front right.
Shadow B will move toward the front right.
Shadow B will elongate and become more oval-shaped.
Shadow C will move toward the front right.
Shadow C will elongate and possibly become more trapezoid-shaped rather than rectangular.
Shadow D will move toward the front right.
Shadow D will elongate diagonally toward the front right.
If the light source moves to the back right, shadow A will move toward the front left.
Shadow A will elongate diagonally toward the front left.
Shadow B will move toward the front left.
Shadow B will elongate and become more oval-shaped.
Shadow C will move toward the front left.
Shadow C will elongate and possibly become more trapezoid-shaped.
